title: Gaste = flabbered
text: This place is monumentally huge! There is so much to see it is hard to know where to begin.Actually it was quite easy to know where to begin because a helpful member of staff pointed me in the right direction. But that isn't quite what I mean. What I mean is, it is difficult to know which bit to focus on first when writing about it, as there is so much, so very much.I bought a ticket for the Residenz and the Treasury and made my way in following red signs. I was guided from room to ornate room dripping with paintings, furniture, tapestries and assorted royal blingery any one of which you could write a book about. After a while (and I appreciate how ignorant this makes me sound) it all starts to blur into one and I found myself thinking "I'm sure I've been in this room before." The endless complex of rooms, corridors, chambers and antechambers had me wondering if when I came out I was going to emerge in Stuttgart.However, I made my way round what I think was most of the rooms that are open to visitors. I think there were about 16 million of them but I lost count part way. There were throne rooms (several) bed rooms (both ceremonial and for sleeping), reception rooms, a chapel, a room housing a collection of bronze statues, a room housing bizarre and unsettling religious relics, a room housing gold rings, two turtle doves and for all I know a partridge in a very royal pear tree. It's all a bit of a blur.While my comments may sound flippant this was part of the joy of visiting this site - and it really was a joy. You could let it all wash over you and just be blown away by the scale and richness of the rooms on display.Eventually I came to the end and noticed that I had done the tour without the benefit of the free audio guides. So I did it again.Occasionally I found myself standing back unable to decide if a room made mostly out of gold was either the most beautiful room I had ever seen or the most hideous. However, the one thing I was always sure about is that I wouldn't like to dust it.If you're in Munich and have a two or three months to kill you really must visit the Residenz. I have never been anywhere like it.

title: Amazing Display of Wealth
text: We visited in the winter, so this turned out to be a great indoor activity for a cold, snowy day.  It was worth it to get the combined ticket (Residenz, treasury, opera theater) that came with a self-paced audio guide. Allot at least 4 hours to see all three; more if you enjoy digging into every single recording on the audio guide.  Room after room of tremendous royal wealth and pageantry are on display throughout the entire Residenz complex.  The grotto and Antiquarium are definitely the highlights.  There are also several ingeniously designed pieces of furniture in the rooms for the mechanically inclined.  As some have noted, much of the structure has been restored.  However, don't get too hung up over that. You'll be hard pressed to find anything in Europe that doesn't bear the scars of WWII.  What you see on display today includes the most important original pieces of art along with rooms were painstakingly recreated using original pieces saved from the war.  The antiquarium and grotto alone are worth the price of admission, and there is enough grandeur surviving from the restoration to impart a good sense what life must have been like during the time of the kings.

It is, however, still very nice to see. There are 130+ rooms to see plus the treasury. We only had two hours to spare, so skipped the treasury (you can buy tickets for both together or separately at The Residenz, but not online). Two hours was not enough to do justice to the palace and we had to skip the audio guide too. So I would recommend 3 to 4 hours to do this place justice. Audio guides are available for free with the ticket, but if you are on express visit, you can get by reading fairly well done signage which is in every room in German and English.

After the first half-dozen rooms where each description (both text and audio available in English) has a coda of "reconstructed based on period piece designs..," you start getting a bit jaded. This is particularly true since most the of rooms are empty or partially furnished with items that were not there originally. It's a sad commentary on the enormous cultural cost of war that's often ignored behind the cost in lives, economic stability, etc. Take the short tour route and save energy for other attractions.

title: Massive building with confusing directions inside
text: Right in the centre of Munich this building suffered badly in the Allied Bombing in 1944, but has been faithfully restored and a lot of the artifacts that could be removed were in safe keeping before the bombing and have since been returned. There are a selection of arrows directing you around but I found these to be confusing and not as easy to use as I had hoped often doubling back on myself. There is a free brochure showing the floor plan with numbered rooms, but I couldn't find these numbers displayed anywhere in the actual rooms. Had these been prominently displayed it would have made life so much easier for finding my way around. There is a lot to see and I spent around two hours here, but would have been a few minutes less if directions were better.

title: spectacular restoration with relics (photos allowed!)
text: Among the top palaces we've seen, this one has a few distinguishing features that make it stand out, including relics, extensive audio in several languages, and permission to take photos (no flash).TIP:  If you are planning on visiting 3 or more castles/palaces in Germany, consider buying the 14 day Mehrtagesticket that allows you to get into 40+ castles/palaces (26 Euros for one adult or 46 Euros for a family).Of the 2 dozen castles/palaces I have visited, the Residenz has possibly the best interior with 90+ furnished rooms full of history as far back as the 1300's, with many aspects having been restored or rebuilt after WWII. Among the many rooms, one displays holy relics (i.e., bones of saints--not for the faint of heart, so skip this room if you don't want to see them). There is an English audio guide that explains many important rooms, or you can just read the panels and accelerate your pace--the best version of a guided tour short of a personal one-on-one guide.  There are seats every few rooms that allows the visitor to rest their tired feet a bit before continuing. We took numerous photos throughout the castle, something that is not allowed at many other sites. We spent more than an hour here before we had to leave for another already-scheduled tour, but this place is worth a lot of time, and has more rooms on display than most sites.

This is a Munich MUST SEE.

title: Largest City Palace In Germany
text: The Residence is located in central Munich just a few short blocks walking distance from the Marienplatz.  It is the former royal palace of the Wittelsbach monarchs of Bavaria and is the largest city palace in Germany.  It served as the seat of government and residence of the Bavarian kings, dukes, and electors for 410 years (1508-1918).  Throughout the palace are exquisitely decorated rooms ‚Äì furniture and paintings, tapestries, treasures, porcelain and religious devotional items.  Climbing the Imperial Staircase you enter the Imperial Hall, the oldest and largest room in the Residence at 217 feet long.  It houses a collection of antique sculptures and busts, hence the name "Antiquarium".  The various State rooms are themselves works of art with richly decorated, walls, ceilings and floors and filled with expensive furniture and tapestries.  The richly gilded gold walls and ceiling of the Ancestral Gallery contain paintings showing the extensive ancestral history of the Elector family tree and was used to justify selection to the thrown of the Holy Roman Empire.  Within the Residence is the Wittelsbachs‚Äô collection of Far Eastern art and over 500 pieces of East Asian porcelain and lacquered items.  There is also an extensive collection of religious relics and liturgical pieces (chalices, crucifixes, etc.).  Within the Treasury, housed in a secure section of the Residence, are the crown jewels of Bavaria as well as a vast collection of jewels, royal insignia, goldsmith's work, jeweled chests, enamels, crystal objects and ivories that have been collected over the centuries by the rulers of Bavaria. At the end of the 18th century, the Bavarian prince also received the entire Palatine treasure and in the 19th century other treasures were added as a result of the secularization of many churches and monasteries.  Of note is the St George's reliquary and the Augsburg silver clock.  The Residence is open from 9 AM to 6 PM April through 15 October and until 5 PM 16 October to March.  Tours are self-guided with free audio-guide included in the price of admission.  Admission to either the Residence or the Treasury is 7 euro, 6 euro reduced rate or a combination ticket to both is 11 euro, 9 euro reduced rate.

title: Takes 3 hours to visit the Residence Museum and Treasury
text: The combo ticket for the Residence Museum and Treasury is only 9 E for seniors. We spent 1 hour in the Treasury and 2 hours viewing the many rooms in the palace - good value for the money spent. At the end of our morning visit, we were overwhelmed by the palace decor. Enter the museum from the Max Joseph Platz. About mid-way along the palace is a doorway - go through that, past a small courtyard to the ticket office. The audio desk provides free audioguides for both the Treasury and the Residence rooms. We began with the Treasury and when finished, the clerk at the audio desk re-programmed our audioguide for the Residence rooms. We found that the Treasury had items labelled in both German and English with shorter descriptions of the objects than that given on the audioguide. Definitely need the audioguide, however, for explanations of the purpose of the palace rooms and their decor. WC are located just to the right of the entry into the Treasury room - a long flight of stairs, though, up to the free WC. Another WC is behind the door marked 00 in the Grotto. WC are not marked on the layout map.We used 1 hour to see the Treasury with more time spent in Rooms 1 to 5 than in Rooms 6-10. The first 5 rooms held the Wittelbach collection of jewels, royal regalia, reliquaries while the next 4 rooms held glassware, dinnerware, and most notable a silver replica of Trajean's column. In rooms 1-5 I enjoyed looking at the 13th, 14th century crowns from Kunigundi and a spikey crown of an English Queen - all lovely with intricate gold work and blue, amethyst, and pearl settings. The small hand sized pearl studded prayer book looked well used, but the jewel studded St. George killing the dragon was dazzling - get up close and walk around the display case to see all of the detail and the thousands of precious stones embedded in the work. Room 4 was less interesting with religious monstrances but the reason behind the king having portable altars (bejewelled and gilted) was interesting when explained. In Room 5 was the crown for King and Queen during their coronation after 1800 - neither were worn, just held/placed at their feet. It was interesting to see that these 10 rooms were located in a secured area with an entry door similar to that used by banks to secure their customers safety boxes.We used 2 hours to visit the 90 rooms in the palace. Take the layout map for these rooms available at the entrance should you wish to know where in the palace you are. There are red arrows showing visitors the way to follow so no fear of getting lost. Photos can be taken and visitors walk around unguided.  Each room has an information board with a red number that is then typed into the audioguide to hear the commentary about the room. Should the commentary be overly long with its explanation, especially when it references the artists who contributed to the decor in the room, just press the "Cancel" button. Or sit on a stool in the rooms to listen to the commentary. Walking through the rooms, I think it becomes obvious where Ludwig II got the idea for his over the top gilded rooms in his Linderhof Palace. There are countless rooms, galleries, and corridors to walk through in this palace as various Wittelbach rulers extended the palace buildings. There was a change in decor with the later rulers in the 1800's but the other rooms all looked similar in their use of gilded ceiling moldings, gilded door panels, gilded table legs, and the use of luxurious fabrics. Where ceiling frescoes had been re-done after the WWII damage they lacked the vibrancy of original paintings seen in other palaces. Certainly some areas were outstanding such as the Grotto (rather grotesque actually), Ancestral Gallery, the Antiquarium Room with many sculptures of notable Romans (caesars) and 2 credenzas with majolica porcelain, private chapels with either gild and blue decor or the Romanesque brick 2 story hall (Court Church of all Saints), and the red porcelain cabinet room with mirrors. There were too many audience rooms and reception/waiting rooms. All of the palace rooms seemed to be for adults; I wondered how royal children entertained themselves or what type of rooms they had.This palace was the main attraction for me in the old town of Munich and was certainly worth the time and good value for the money spent.

title: June 2018: Diamonds, statues, paintings, & decorative arts - room after room; Must see!  practical tips for visiting
text: The Residenz  was a palace for the Wittelsbach dynasty.  Now, it is a modern museum.   Bombing destroyed almost all of the original building during World War 2 (Munich was the birthplace of the Nazi movement, and was an Allied target for that reason).  What you experience when you visit is a recreation of the palace; filled with paintings, tapestries, jewels, clocks, and other decorative arts.   The collection‚Äôs scope is amazing and a must-see.  The recreation includes the Cuvillies theater, a beautiful Rococo masterpiece (clearly modeled after the theater at Versailles, but more intimate and ‚Äì for the tourist ‚Äì far more accessible).  The Cuvillies theater‚Äôs interior is one of the few remaining original parts of the palace.  Before bombs destroyed the palace, caretakers disassembled the interior, and stored it out of harm‚Äôs way.  The one other original part of the palace to survive is the antiquarium ‚Äì a renaissance hall filled with statuary and paintings.   The antiquarium alone is worth the visit.How much time: it‚Äôll take at least four hours, easily, and you may have time to walk through all the rooms, but not enough to immerse yourself in the exhibits.   One could spend the whole day ‚Äì maybe two ‚Äì to see everything.Tickets: you can buy tickets for the residenz or the theater, or both.   Do both.   The best ticket is the Mehrtagesticket ‚Äì 44 Euros ‚Äì for two adults for 14 days to visit all the Bavarian state museums and gardens.  It will get you into the museum and theater.   Kids 18 and under are free.Getting there: don‚Äôt drive.  Use buses or the underground.   The closest underground stop is Odeonsplatz. Alternatively, you could hop off the U at Marienplatz, see the Rathaus and the animatronic clock, then walk to the Residenz (or vice-versa).  Buses are also easy to use.  Alternatively, you could rent a bike.  There‚Äôs a huge bike rack in the Max Joseph Platz.  Note: bikes are big in Munich ‚Äì they‚Äôre everywhere.  Strangely, Germans, for the most part, don‚Äôt seem to wear bike helmets.  If renting a bike, I‚Äôd sure get a helmet.  There‚Äôs a lot of automotive traffic on the streets and lots of pedestrians in the pedestrian malls; all making for potential spills that could ruin a trip in a moment.Who will enjoy:  Adults and teens who can appreciate history and/or art will enjoy the visit.  Anyone younger than 13 will likely endure the visit, but with not that much humor.Staff:  they speak enough English, for the most part, to help you get by.  As always knowing some German is not only polite and greatly appreciated, but also an excellent way to truly enjoy your visit.Food: you can find something to eat at a couple wine bars on Residenzstrasse, or other restaurants nearby, but not in the museum.  If you want water, like the rest of Germany, you need to pack your own.   Water fountains seem to be an American thing.  You can refill your water bottle in the WC.Entrances:  there are two that count ‚Äì from the Residenztrasse and Max-Joseph-Platz.  The platz entrance is the easier to use. These are the only two entrances that get you to the ticket desk.  Go here first, then go to the other entrances to see courtyards and the theater.Selfie sticks:  leave them at home.  They‚Äôre verboten!!  And, the staff is obsessed with keeping them out of the museum.Prepping for the weather: even in June, it can get cold and you can get soaked with rain.  Our day in Munich was rainy and mostly in the fifties to sixties.  We had umbrellas, (courtesy of our hotel) and they were worth the trouble of carrying as otherwise we‚Äôd have been soaked.  Make sure you pack a sweater, at least, and, to be well prepared, a water resistant wind-breaker.

title: Beautiful museum, don't miss the Treasury
text: My husband and I toured the Residenz while using the audio tour.  We really enjoyed ourselves and learned  a lot about Bavarian history.  Definitely see both the palace living quarters and the Treasury; it's worth it.  Allow a minimum of two hours, three would be better.The Residenz was the in-town home of the very wealthy ruling family of Bavaria, the Wittelsbachs.  The first buildings at this site were erected in 1385.  The Treasury houses the riches of the Wittelsbach family that ranges in time from the early Middle Ages to the Neo-classical period.  It includes the crown of the English Princess Blanche (Blanche of Lancaster), the oldest known surviving crown of England.  When she married into the Wittelsbach family it became their property as part of her dowry.  It is also known as the Bohemian Crown or the Palatine Crown; it is thought to have been made after about 1370 and is the best surviving example of Gothic goldsmithing.  It looks as if it would belong to a fairy-tale princess.  It, the Bavarian Crown jewels, the Crown of Therese of Bavaria, and the statue of St. George and the Dragon are the absolute highlights.
